item.title: Ticket #1004 (A less privileged user's post 'disappears' after they make an edit) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
I think arguments can be made for both policies (disallowing further edits, and allowing further edits.)

However, if edits are allowed, it seems wrong to make the post disappear (EDIT: to clarify, make the post disappear from the public side of the blog). What would be ideal is that the edits are submitted as a draft revision, while the original post remains published. Pretty much impossible given the current structure. I've been trying to think of a way that this could be accomplished. All I can think of is that on edit, an additional post is created with a status of "revision draft", that has some sort of "is_revision_of" value that points to the original post. If the admin approves the changes, they are put into the post that has already been published, and the temporary "revision draft" is destroyed.

The "new users can submit drafts" process is quite young, and it would be good to give it some more consideration, trying to think of how it might be used.

I used the process in 1.3 CVS to run a blog with over 150 users that could submit drafts. I hacked the interface quite a bit in order to make things better.

Some thoughts: Users who can submit drafts should not be able to edit each others posts... only their own. They also should not be shown the Dashboard screen... too confusing. Also, it isn't obvious to new users what button they should press to submit a post for approval (see here: ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=1097 ). There needs to be a better way of notifying the admin that posts are waiting for approval (see here: ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=1098 )

Also, it's not really obvious who has submitted a post for approval to the admin. All he gets is a list of draft titles. Perhaps we need a subpage of "Manage" that has a "drafts queue" page. If this whole "submit drafts for approval" concept were fleshed out, it could really open up a lot of possibilities for group blogs.

item.title: Ticket #1004 (A less privileged user's post 'disappears' after they make an edit) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
We are not consistent in the way we handle the new_users_can_blog setting. When creating new users, users.php sets the user_level to 0, 1, or 2 depending on whether users cannot write anything, can write only drafts, or can publish.

Some places such as user_can_create_post() and user_can_edit_post() assume the user was setup with the necessary permissions and simply check if the user_level is 0, 1, or 2 without referencing the new_users_can_blog setting.

Other places think that a new user has a level of 1 and that new_users_can_blog gives level 1 users varying powers.

We need to pick a method. I prefer having users.php set the level to where it needs to be. That way we can ignore new_users_can_blog once a user is created.

So, I've updated the patch to make consistent use of user_can_create_post() and user_can_create_draft() and eliminate references to new_users_can_blog outside of user creation context.

Also, I think users who can't publish should be disallowed from editing published posts.

item.dc:creator: idanso
item.description:
The wpautop filter, enabled by default on Wordpress 1.5, produces not well formed XHTML in some cases.

One such case occurs when the input has a 'pee' block contained within a 'div' block, and there is a newline, followed by atext between the end of the 'pee' block and the end of the 'div' block.

In such a case, wpautop will open a 'pee' block at the start of the text block, but will not close it.

For example: <div> <p>Hello</p> World</div>

Will product: <div> <p>Hello</p> <p>World</div>
